                   Linguistic niches emerge from pressures at multiple timescales
                                 Molly Lewis                                           Michael C. Frank
                              mll@stanford.edu                                       mcfrank@stanford.edu
                          Department of Psychology                                  Department of Psychology
                              Stanford University                                       Stanford University
                              Abstract                                    However, the presence of communicative pressures at the
                                                                       pragmatic timescale is unable to explain cross-linguistic vari-
   What accounts for the vast diversity in the world’s languages?
   We explore one possibility: languages adapt to their linguis-       ability in linguistic structure. That is, why does Polish have
   tic environment (Linguistic Niche Hypothesis; Lupyan & Dale,        rich morphology but English relatively sparse? A growing
   2010). Recent studies have found support for this hypothesis        body of work argues that this variability may be due to cog-
   through correlations between aspects of the environment and
   linguistic structure. We synthesize this previous work and find     nitive constraints internal to the language learner (Chater &
   that languages spoken in cold, small regions tend to be more        Christiansen, 2010) as well as properties of the environmental
   complex across a range of linguistic features. We also test         context (Nettle, 2012). This hypothesis, termed the Linguis-
   a novel prediction of the Linguistic Niche Hypothesis by ex-
   amining the learnability of languages for first-language, child     tic Niche Hypothesis (Lupyan & Dale, 2010; Wray & Grace,
   learners.                                                           2007), suggests that language systems adapt to the internal
   Keywords: Linguistic Niche Hypothesis; language evolution           and external pressures of the linguistic environment.

   Central to this hypothesis is the notion of a timescale:            pends largely on the presence of a possible mechanism link-
there are different units of time over which processes operate,        ing environmental features to aspects of language systems. A
and processes at shorter timescales influence those at longer          range of proposals have been suggested (Nettle, 2012). For
timescales (Blythe, 2015, see also Fig. 1). At the shortest
timescale are individual utterances in communicative inter-
actions (pragmatics). At a longer timescale is language ac-
quisition. Both experimental and modeling work suggest that
communicative interactions at the pragmatic timescale influ-
ence processes like word learning at the acquisition timescale
(e.g., Baldwin, 1991; McMurray, Horst, & Samuelson, 2012;
Frank, Goodman, & Tenenbaum, 2009; Frank & Goodman,
2014).
   In addition to pragmatics and acquisition, a third relevant
timescale is language evolution: the timescale over which en-
tire language systems change. As for acquisition, there is evi-
dence that language systems may be the product of processes            Figure 1: Pressures on language, internal and external to the
at the pragmatic timescale. For example, languages univer-             cognitive system at three different timescales. The Linguistic
sally structure semantic space to reflect optimal equilibria be-       Niche Hypothesis suggests that language evolution is influ-
tween communicative pressures (e.g., Kemp & Regier, 2012;              enced by the internal and external pressures in the particular
Regier, Kay, & Khetarpal, 2007; Baddeley & Attewell, 2009).            environmental context in which a language is spoken.

Figure 2: Relationship between environmental and linguistic variables, which each point represents a language. Red (positive)
and blue (negative) indicate models where the environmental variable is a significant predictor of the linguistic variable. Lines
show the fixed effect estimate (slope) and intercept of the mixed effect model. Number of languages varies across plots due to
variation in the number of overlapping languages across datasets.
viation precipitation. Figure 3: Languages spoken in cold, small regions tend to be more complex. The bar plots show the loadings on the first
two principal components for the environmental variables (n = 7; orange) and language variables (n = 5; green). The scatter
plots show the relationship between the first two principal components for both sets of variables. Each point corresponds to
a language, and lines show the linear fit from the mixed effect model. Significance and direction of a linear relationship are
indicated by the coloring of the scatterplot (blue: significant and negative; red: significant and positive).

principal components associated with the variance for the en-                                                                                                                                                         ing to hot and rainy regions. The second component loads
vironmental variables and the linguistic variables, and then fit                                                                                                                                                      most heavily on variables related to the size of the region a
